coredata.dc:title: Dielectric dispersion in optical electron transfer in solution
coredata.dc:creator: Delahay, Paul
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Dielectric dispersion causes the outer-sphere reorganization free energy to vary with photon energy in optical electron transfer. The resulting distortion of the spectral response for photoelectron emission may yield misleading evidence about the emission yield versus photon energy relationship. Dispersion is taken into account in the calculation of emission threshold energies and the correlation between optical and thermal electron transfer. Results are given for V2+, Cr2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Fe(CN)6 4−.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 96. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 April 1983 DIELECTRIC DISPERSION IN OPTICAL ELECTRON TRANSFER IN SOLUTION Paul DELAHAY Department of Chemistry, New York University. New York, New York 10003. USA Received 7 February 1983 Dielectric dispersion causes the outer-sphere reorganization free energy to vary with photon energy in optical electron transfer- The resulting distortion of the spectral response for photoelectron emission may yield misleading evidence about the emission yield versus photon energy relationship. Dispersion is taken into account in the calculation of emission thresh- old energies and the correlation between optical and thermal electron transfer. Results are given for V2*, Cr2*, Mn2'*", Fe2"1', Co2*, Fe(CN)^~. 1. Introduction Optical electron transfer in solution can be inter- preted [1] on the basis of ideas transposed from theo- ries of thermal electron transfer [1 3]. Thus, optical electron transfer is considered to be fast in comparison with subsequent reorganization of nuclear positions- The free energy of reorganization R is equated to the sum of inner- and outer-sphere contributions,/?^ and Rout. These are treated microscopically (/?m, section 4) and as non-equilibrium polarization of a continuous medium (section 2), respectively. The resulting expres- sion for -Rout [1 4] contains the optical dielectric con- stant Cop of the solvent. This quantity varies with the photon energy E at which optical electron transfer oc- curs because of dielectric dispersion of the solvent. The free energy Rg^ therefore is a function ofE in contrast to the thermal case in which fipp is a constant, e.g. op = 1.77 for water at 25 C. The dependence ofRy^ on E has significant implications which are examined in the present paper for the case of photoelectron emis- sion by aqueous solutions in the 5 11.5 eV range [5]. 2. Free energy of outer-sphere reorganization with dielectric dispersion The real and imaginary parts of the dielectric con- stant of a non-ideally transparent liquid are ei = n2 - ft2 and e^ = Ink, respectively. There, n is the refractive index and A the absorption coefficient of the medium. The displacement current in such a dielectric is propor- tional to the real part e^, and consequently the elec- tronic polarization of the medium depends on ei at the appropriate frequency in the optical range. The value of/!2 k2 must be taken at the photon energy " at which electron transfer occurs. Thus, electron transfer is caused by photon absorption, and the elec- tronic polarization of the medium therefore responds to the change of ionic valence of the photoionized species in the same scale of time as photon absorption. The quantity rft- k^ therefore must be substituted for the optical dielectric constant in the expression SoiR^t.Thus, ^outCE")" K"2 - ^-2)-1 - es-1] ^/2a , (1) where e, is the static dielectric constant of the solvent, e the electronic charge, and a the radius of the assumed spherical boundary between inner- and outer-sphere re- gions. The reduced and oxidized species (denoted re- spectively by the subscripts r and o) have somewhat different cavity radii, and one sets a = la^a^Ka^ + Og) as is done for thermal electron transfer [6]. Fig. 1 shows the effect of dielectric dispersion on ^out^) "^q- (1)- Results are displayed as the varia- tion of the ratio F afR^^fE) ai E to the value of ^outO -77) fbr "2 = \ 77 and k1 = (water at 25 C). Values ofn and k were taken from ref. [7]. The shape 0 009-2614/83/0000-0000/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland 613 Volume 96. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 0 8 Elev) 1 ip 1 - Plot of ilie ratio / " ot" the ouier- phcre rcorgiiniZJtion free encrgi /i;oul( ') ->l the pholon energy E to /?out(l-77) niiiipuicd for n2 = 1.77 Jnd A-2 = 0. ot' (he curve in tig. 1 is accounted for by the effect of normal and anomalous dispersion (absorption bands at S.2 and 10-0 eV). It is seen that R^(E) can be as low as 65';r of/?ym( 1.77) and that Ry^(E) changes quite rapidly in ralher narrow intervals off". Fig. 1 applies tu pure water. and variations ot'F may be somewhat different for concentrated electrolytes, especially in the range of absorption bands of the anion (charge transfer to the solvent). The variations of e^ in (1) with electrolyte concentration are not significant since e^'1 tor aqueous solutions is small in comparison with (^ -A-2)-l. 3. Determination of threshold energies by extrapolation Plioioelectron emission by solutions is studied [5] b\ tieicrmimng the number of electrons collected (on an elecuode above the solution) per incident photon as a function of (lie photon energy E. The emission yield }' thus measured is proportional to the emission current density of theory [S] to a good measure under actual experimental conditions. It was shown [8] that >' is proportional to (E - Ey. where \ is the thresh- old energy of the species being photoionized and p = 2 or 5/2. Tins relationship follo-.vs from a more general equation for Y under suitable simplifying conditions. The exponent p = 2 corresponds to the normal case in which image forces are taken into account at the solu- tion vacuum interface. The value p = 5/2 holds if one assumes that the image forces are negligible. The threshold energy E^ is determined from a plot of yVP against E. This procedure was applied to water [9], inorganic anions [10] and cations [II], and weak acids and bases [12] in aqueous solution. It was found that the exponent p = 5/2 gave better fits to linear plots thanp = 2 for species with \ < 8 eV- Conversely. the exponent p = 2 was preferable to 5/2 foiE^ >, 8 eV. The statistical evidence for these values o!p was fairly unambiguous in most cases, but the underlying reasons for the choice ofp = 5/2 were mystifying. The absence of image forces is difficult to account for, and anyhow tlie magnitude of image forces would conceivably de- pend on the kinetic energy of mobile electrons in the liquid and not on the absolute value of the photon energy. These puzzling results are accounted for by the effect of dispersion on RQ^(E) as will now be shown- Tlie threshold energy is the sum of several contribu- tions one of which is tlie free energy of outer-sphere reorganization R^ (section 4). Call E the threshold energy at Y = 0 in the linear extrapolation plot of Y^P against E. One has R^ =^Sui at " = f, and a differ- ent ^outW at E>E . Tlie value ofE^ in (E - E^P therefore is not the constant E but the quantity, 't= " -y?out-^o. ( ')L (2) depending on E. Since R^(E) may differ from./?^ by several tenths ofelectronvolt, plots of Y^P against E are distorted- Variations of( " - \)2 with E - E are shown in fig. 2 foiE = 6 and 8 eV, respectively. Values of E ", were calculated from fig. 1 and the values of ^ut = \ -02 and 0.81 eV at E = 6 and 8 eV, respec- tively. These values of/?^ correspond to the typical case of-R(,m(l .77) = 1.15 eV for the cations of sec- tion 4- Tlie curve ( - E^)2 versus ( - E ) foiE = 6 eV in fig. 2 is quite close to the points representing ( - E0)312. This result foUows directly from fig. 1. The ratio F decreases quite rapidly with increasing E in the 6-7.6 eV range, and consequently ( " ~ E^)2 increases more rapidly than (E E^)2. Conversely, the curve (E - \)2 versus E - E for E = 8 eV in fig. 2 is fairly close to the quadratic dependence (E \ )~ because the decrease of F between E = 8.6 and 9.4 eV is less pronounced than the variations of F for "t = 6 eV. Apparent variation ofp from 5/2 to t)14 Volume 96. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 April 1983 E-E?(eV) Fig. 2. Spectral response for emission (E - Ef)2 with consider- ation of dispersion compared with the responses (E E y2 and ( - f^)572 without dispersion. 2 for the results of fig. 2 are solely due to the change of^?om( ") with E as a result of dispersion. The statis- tical evidence in rets. [10 12] upon which the choice ofp = 5/2 was based therefore is misleading and does not provide any proof that the (E E^l2 relation- ship is in fact observed. A more elaborate analysis must be developed on the basis of the quadratic de- pendence regardless of photon energy and with con- sideration of the variations of -/? ,..( ') with photon energy. 4. Calculated free energies of emission versus experimental threshold energies The free energy AG^ for photoelectron emission by an aqueous solution of a donor D(aq) is [5,11] AGn, = AGu + AG +R + le|Ax . Here, AG^ and AG are the changes of free energy for the reactions, D(aq) + H^aq) = D-"-(aq) + ^(g) , ^(g) =11-^+0^). respectively;^ is the reorganization free energy taken as a positive quantity for convenience; and AX is the difference between the surface potentials x[D(aq)] of (3) the solution of D(aq) and ^(HaO) of water. One has [13] AG^ = 4.48 ~0.05 eV on the basis of a current determination [14] of the real free energy ofhydration ( 11-25 eV) of the proton. This value of AGy includes the contribution of the surface potential XCH^O) of water. The latter cannot be measured but can be estimated (0.08 0.06 eV [15]). The surface potential x[D(aq)] is generally different from that of water, and the experimentally measurable [15] differ- ence AX therefore appears in (3). Since the surface po- tential pertains to the change of potential from the liquid to vacuum, a positive value of AX corresponds to a higher barrier to emission than for AX = 0. Hence, the quantity le)Ax in (3) is preceded by a positive sign. The correction in quite minor anyhow since ielAx is in general smaller than 0.05-0-1 eV in ab- solute value [15]. The reorganization free energy isR =R^(E)+ R-^, where R-^ is computed from the bond-streiching model used for thermal electron transfer [1]. Thus, ^n=^V/-(A<7o)2, (4) where N is the number ofligands of the donor D(aq); A<7Q is the change of equilibrium positions for vibra- tion from the reduced species D(aq) to D^aq); and/ is the reduced force constant [6], /=2/,/o/(f,+/o). (4) is based is somewhat sim- plified for hexaquo ions, for instance- The/values from re f- [16] previously used [4] were computed from a Urey Bradley potential in ref. [17]. This gives/values which are definitely too low, as was pointed out [18] to the writer, and experimen- tal force constants must be used. One has [6], /I=4lr2^c2^. Such a calculation from kinetic data is reliable for Fe2"^34" [6]. 5. Correlation between optical and thermal electron transfer Optical and thermal electron transfer were corre- lated in ref. [4] without consideration of dielectric dispersion. It was sliown that the outer-sphere reorga- nization free energy R^t ^or electron exchange (e.g., between Fe2"1" and Fe3"1") is practically the same as /?oui tor photoelectron emission. The inner-sphere term R^ for exchange is twice R-^ for emission since two ions are involved in exchange and only one in emission. Thus.^om =Rouiand ^fn = ^in'and the reorganization free energy for exchange isR^- =R + /?, . Tlie effect of dielectric dispersion will now be considered. bib Volume 96, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 April 1983 Table 2 Calculated and experimental free energies of activation for electron exchange J?a) (eV) A^oUt^(eV) H.C)(eV) AG^^calc.) (3) and data in table 1. b) From .Rout in table 1 and the corresponding/?out(l-77). c) From ref. [4]. d) For Rin in table 1. e) From ref. [ 1 ]. The quantity ^?out ^or c^h^S ls generally com- puted for CQ,) = 1.77 for dilute aqueous solutions at 25 C, that is..R-out ^outO -77)- Hence, R^=R+R^+^R^, (7) where the correction for dispersion is AR^m = ^oui0 -77) - R^(E),R^(E) beingcomputed at E = ",- The free energy' of activation AG^ for electron ex- change without net change of free energy is [1 3], AG^ = w + ^R^, where u' is the work required to bring from infinity in solution the two reactants to- gether in the activated complex. Values ofAG^ from (7) are listed in table 2 with experimental values taken from ref- [1]. This compari- son, it must be stressed, is only tentative because cal- culated values ofAG^ should be compared with the activation free energy for electron transfer within the precursor complex [6]. Data are included only for couples for which AG^ can be computed reasonably well from AC* = i-R-^ + w [1 3]- Thus. exchange for Co747^ is known to be anomalously slow [19]. The "experimental" value AG^ = 0.75 eV for Mn2"'73"1' obtained in ref. [1] from the Marcus cross relationship differs markedly from the value AG^ = 1.06 eV com- puted from./?^ Experimental (0.47 eV [1]) and calcu- lated (0.31 eV) AG^ values for Fe(CN)|-73- also dis- agree. Discrepancies in table 2 can be interpreted on the basis of values ofR^ computed from AG^ = ^R^ + w [1 3] by using the experimental AC* in table 2 and calculated values of^^ [= .r?oui(l .77)]. Errors on AG* and R^^ affect the value ofR^, and application of the equation for AG^ is assumed to bejustifled- Values ofR\n thus obtained obviously must be viewed with caution. One has R-^ = 1 -09, 1 -39, 0.69 eV for V2^, Cr2-1-, Fe2-1-, respectively, versus 1.41,1.27,0.73 eV in table 1. One concludes that the main source of discrepancy between calculated and experimental AG^ values in table 2 is mostly the high R-^ of table I for y2+/3+ ^d t^g hif^i E^ (and consequently high R) for pg2+/3+ Agreement for Cr2"1'^3-1' is reasonable. In conclusion, consideration of dispersion is essen- tial in future determinations of experimental llireshold energies. Free energies of emission computed from data independent of emission generally agree with available threshold energies within extrapolation error. Correla- tion between optical and thermal electron transfer pro- vides, whenever feasible, further verification of the self- consistency of all data. head.ce:title: Dielectric dispersion in optical electron transfer in solution

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, New York University, New York, New York 10003, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Dielectric dispersion causes the outer-sphere reorganization free energy to vary with photon energy in optical electron transfer. The resulting distortion of the spectral response for photoelectron emission may yield misleading evidence about the emission yield versus photon energy relationship. Dispersion is taken into account in the calculation of emission threshold energies and the correlation between optical and thermal electron transfer. Results are given for V2+, Cr2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Fe(CN)6 4−.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: J. Chem. Soc. Faraday Trans. II

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: B.S. Brunschwig, C. Creutz, D.H. Macartney, T.-K. Sham and N. Sutin, Discussions Faraday Soc., to be published.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Infrared and Raman spectra of inorganic and coordination compounds
Infrared and Raman spectra of inorganic and coordination compounds
